The fish balls were very refreshing to eat, made from silver pearl fish, with no fishy taste at all.

She had an extra bowl, while Mama Chao was having her meal at the small table, secretly observing the etiquette of the young princess consort. Seeing that she ate without any pretension, enjoying her food with good posture, Mama Chao couldn't help but nod in approval.

After Mama Chao brought this news, Nanny Nan and the others visibly relaxed.

Though it was said he would return in three days, Huiyin didn't actually expect Li Cheng to come back so punctually. However, Mama Chao and Nanny Fan began their preparations. They replaced the bed curtains with a new four-joy embroidered canopy featuring a qilin sending a child motif, adorned with pearls at the corners and long tassels. On the table, several ruyi scepters were placed, and next to it stood a peony-painted dressing table inlaid with gold. The armchairs and daybed were covered again with dragon-phoenix auspicious cloth.

A pair of copper crane lampstands held two dragon-phoenix wedding candles as thick as a baby's arm. Even the wedding cakes had been bought.

"The young prince has returned, the young prince has returned..."

Huiyin was sitting nearby reading a book when she heard the servants in the mansion spreading the news. Before long, Mama Chao came in and said, "Young princess consort, please freshen up and dress. This evening at dusk, the young prince will perform the wedding rites with you."

Nanny Nan had Le Yun and Fugui come over to help her with the hair and makeup. Perhaps because the wedding day had been delayed for too long, the Zheng family was determined to make sure Li Cheng saw their young lady, the most beautiful woman in Jizhou, in all her glory.

Her jet-black hair was neatly coiled up, with a pearl-inlaid golden mandarin duck hairpin with interwoven patterns in the center of the bun. On both sides were adorned with gold filigree gemstone hairpins, from which hung coral and jade tassels. Standing up, with the help of the servants, she changed into a double-layered crimson silk wide-sleeved jacket, the edges embroidered with gemstone pomegranates. Over it, she wore a hundred-birds-to-phoenix cape, paired with a twelve-panel hundred sons and hundred blessings skirt. The train of the skirt trailed five feet behind, embroidered with various colored beads, and her waist was adorned with a jade pendant that jingled softly as she walked.

...

On the hot summer day, Li Cheng returned and, after a brief moment, handed over his duties to his subordinates. Only then did he remove his armor.

Ever since the campaign began, Li Cheng had always led from the front, charging ahead in battle. This time, he had taken an arrow to his right shoulder. Fortunately, the wound wasn't deep, but because he had galloped back, sweat had soaked the wound, causing some rot. Gritting his teeth, he had the military doctor come and change his bandages again.

The military doctor, who had once been an imperial physician in the mansion, advised, "Young prince, the wound must not come into contact with water. And please, don't wear such heavy armor anymore. Now that you've returned victorious, it's a good time to rest and recover."

Li Cheng pondered for a moment. "I will remember what you said, Doctor."

Seeing the red decorations around, the military doctor lowered his voice further, "Young prince, it's best to abstain from alcohol, and also... from marital relations. Wait until the wound has healed before..."

Li Cheng was taken aback.

After the military doctor left, Mama Chao entered.

Clearly having overheard the doctor's advice, she quickly said, "Young prince, should I speak to Princess Zheng? I'm sure she'll understand. Your health should be the priority. After all, this marriage was arranged by the Prince of Wei, and you didn't wish to marry her."

In Mama Chao's eyes, after observing Princess Zheng these past few days, she seemed quiet and unintrusive. But still, Princess Zheng couldn't compare to the young prince she had nursed.

Unexpectedly, Li Cheng said, "Mother, marriage is no trivial matter. In the future, I may have many women, but she will only have me as her husband. The wedding has already been delayed for several days. If we don't consummate the marriage now, how will others view her?"

Chao (second tone)

title: Chapter 8
content:
Chapter 8

◎Newlywed Night Conversation◎

The bridal chamber was adorned in a sea of red, and the quilt cover with a mandarin ducks playing in the water pattern was sprinkled with auspicious foods like longan, lotus seeds, and lily bulbs. Now, she was alone in the room.

Huiyin really wanted to pull off the red veil herself, feeling rather bored.

Suddenly, she heard what sounded like kneeling outside, followed by a series of footsteps. The footsteps were steady, and Huiyin wondered if it could be Li Cheng.

Just as she thought so, she sensed someone approaching, and in an instant, the veil was lifted.

The man opposite her wore a first-rank red brocade with python patterns and gold-thread embroidery wedding robe, with a gold-edged auspicious cloud belt around his waist. His ink-black hair was tied with a pure gold dragon crown, featuring flowing silk rosy auspicious cloud patterns, with two azure dragons encircling it. At the top was a precious gem, giving the impression of two dragons protecting the pearl, making him appear tall and noble.

Especially striking was his appearance, which was completely different from what Huiyin had imagined. He had peach blossom eyes, a handsome and somewhat rakish look, resembling those carefree playboys.

Thinking of this, Huiyin felt that one truly couldn’t judge a person by their appearance. This Li Cheng, who looked like this, was actually a devoted lover.

Li Cheng looked at Huiyin with a different gaze. From afar, she was the epitome of a beauty from Yan and Zhao, tall, with an alluring figure, deep eyes, and a straight nose. Her small face and slender, long neck were as white as snow, like a flower of wealth and nobility. A single glance at her could make one’s mind go blank, temporarily forgetting everything.

The two strangers exchanged a glance, and Huiyin stood up to perform a greeting: "Little Prince."

Her voice was very coquettish, not forced but seemingly natural.

Li Cheng felt a bit uncomfortable upon hearing it: "Princess."

Huiyin, who hadn’t seen him before, now found him even more handsome than Li Heng. At the very least, she felt a bit more at ease.

Just as they addressed each other, the lady of ceremonies came in to arrange for them to drink the nuptial cup wine. Huiyin rarely drank alcohol, as alcohol could easily deplete one’s health. Her father, who had indulged in concubines and alcohol over the past few years, had seen his vigor diminish.

Even for women, excessive indulgence could lead to physical weakness.

She took a sip of the wine and placed it back on the table.

After the lady left, they were alone again. Huiyin still didn’t know how Li Cheng felt. She feared that if she made the first move, she might be ridiculed for misinterpreting his feelings.

Fortunately, Li Cheng spoke up in time: "I heard that there were bandits on your way here? Are you alright?"

"Oh, thank you for your concern, Little Prince. I’m fine. Thanks to General Yuwen’s meticulous arrangements, he first placed us in a temple. It rained at that time, and we hid from both the rain and the bandits. By the time we came out, the bandits had already been wiped out," Huiyin said with a smile.

Though her voice was coquettish, she spoke crisply and decisively. Li Cheng looked at her and nodded: "I’m glad to hear that. These days I’ve been fighting in Xiapi, and it must have been tough for you."

Since he showed concern for her, Huiyin felt she should also show concern for him. Thus, she said: "I’m fine, but Prince, you’ve been exerting yourself to the utmost. Have you been injured?"

Li Cheng pointed to his shoulder: "I took an arrow here, but the wound is shallow, nothing serious."

Upon hearing that he was injured, Huiyin immediately said: "Since you’re injured, why were you drinking just now?"

"Because it’s our wedding night," Li Cheng replied without thinking. Even though he might not be able to love her deeply, he still needed to respect her.

Huiyin looked at him seriously: "Is it still bandaged now?"

Li Cheng nodded.

Huiyin looked at him: "Since that’s the case, you can sleep on the bed tonight, and I’ll sleep on the cot beside it. Since you’re injured, you need to rest and recover properly."

Seeing her arrange things so quickly, one might think they were already very familiar with each other, but Li Cheng shook his head: "No, you should sleep on the bed. I’ll sleep on the cot."

"That won’t do. If my parents found out, they would say I’m abusing you," Huiyin’s tender voice did not give in at all.

Most women who met him would be extremely respectful due to his status. However, Zheng was different. She was like a young girl, clearly pampered by her family but not spoiled. While he was away fighting, she showed no displeasure and didn't demand consummation. She quickly eased the awkwardness.

Li Cheng lowered his head. "I can't let you sleep on the couch, can I?"

Huiyin smiled. "Then we'll both sleep on the bed. It's big enough, and we won't touch each other." After that, she added, "I'll go bathe and freshen up first."

It seemed like she was relieved.

Strangely, Li Cheng had never met such a woman in his life. She had the knack for taking charge, even though it was Huaiyin Mansion, and he was the master.

Huiyin bathed and refreshed herself very quickly. She often felt that soaking too long made her skin swell like pork. So, after removing her hairpins and taking a bath, she came out. As she approached, Li Cheng glanced at her and then looked away.

Huiyin climbed over him and lay down on the bed, letting out a comfortable sigh. "Finally, I can lie down. I'm so tired today."

She really just wanted to sleep early that night. The issue of consummation wasn't a priority for her, especially since he was injured and needed to take care of his body.

After saying that, she closed her eyes. But the fragrance from her body made Li Cheng's blood boil, keeping him awake.

Just as Huiyin was about to drift off, a shadow appeared over her. Li Cheng was on top of her, gently kissing her chin. This left her confused but also worried as she said in between breaths, "Your injury..."

"It's fine. Tonight is our wedding night. If we don't consummate, what will people think?" Li Cheng said, perhaps making an excuse.

A princess from Jizhou who didn't consummate her marriage on the first night would become a laughing stock. Huiyin understood this well. The next day, specialized matrons would collect the ceremonial white cloth. If things didn't go well, the princess's authority would be compromised.

Li Cheng's hands moved gracefully, like butterflies in flight, sparing Huiyin much pain.

After their first time, they called for water twice more. Worried his wound might reopen, Huiyin helped him change the bandage.

As she tended to him, Li Cheng looked at her flushed face, extraordinarily beautiful, and cursed himself for being lustful. Thankfully, she believed him.

Huiyin was very skilled. She first cleaned the wound with strong alcohol, removing the blood and surrounding sweat and oils, before applying the medicine powder and swiftly tying the gauze.

Seeing her skill, Li Cheng couldn't help but ask, "How are you so skilled at cleaning wounds?"

Huiyin, of course, couldn't tell the truth that she had often helped Li Heng, his nominal "favorite concubine." Instead, she said, "Naturally, because of my younger brother. He's a few years younger, and when he gets injured, I help him treat it."

After finishing, Huiyin walked back to the bed but felt her legs weaken for a moment. Li Cheng saw this and couldn't help but smile.

After they both lay down, Huiyin tactfully inquired, "How many concubines do you have? That way, I can prepare appropriate gifts. I'm from Jizhou and not familiar with your family's rules."

Li Cheng quickly replied, "I have no concubines. My parents have passed away, and I've been in mourning."

Huiyin was somewhat satisfied but asked again, "Is there someone you care about deeply? I mean, a woman?"

She was straightforward and didn't like beating around the bush. If Li Cheng didn't treat her well, she wouldn't hesitate to assert herself. She had no intention of pretending to be virtuous.

Li Cheng looked at Huiyin, surprised. "Why would you ask that?"

Not receiving a direct answer was telling, so Huiyin playfully said, "If you only want to be a nominal couple, we'll be polite and not interfere with each other. I'll be very considerate. But if you genuinely treat me well, you'll gain a beautiful and affectionate wife who will be devoted to you."

title: Chapter 9
content:
Chapter 9

◎Digging a Hole◎

Granny Chao hadn’t slept all night, deeply worried. She spoke to Nanny Fan, "The Little Prince is injured, and they called for water twice. I don’t know what to say."

Originally, Granny Chao had no intention of informing everyone, because if Nanny Fan knew, then Grand Dowager Wu would know.

The Grand Dowager is the grandmother of the Little Prince. Ever since the Prince of Wu and the Princess passed away, the Grand Dowager has been the only relative of the Little Prince. Now, she resides in Jianye and usually stays with the Empress Dowager of the Prince of Wei.

But this new Princess Zheng has overstepped. If she didn’t know about the Little Prince’s shoulder injury initially, surely she must have noticed during their intimate moments? Granny Chao had thought she was a compassionate person, but it seems she’s more of an enchantress.

Nanny Fan, however, laughed and said, "Granny Chao, the Little Prince's private matters are none of your concern. They are newlyweds; saying too much might backfire."

Hearing Nanny Fan say this, Granny Chao thought to herself that of course, this is what you'd wish for. If the Grand Dowager could catch some fault of the new Princess, she might be able to place the Grand Dowager’s niece, Xun Rou, by the Little Prince's side.

This marriage of the Little Prince was a purely political union to ally with the Marquis of Jizhou. Otherwise, the Grand Dowager had wanted to marry her niece, Xun Rou, to him.

Xun Rou had been by the Grand Dowager’s side since she was seven. Back when the Princess of Wu was alive, she had wanted to marry her niece, Miss Cui, to him, but after the Princess passed away, the topic was never brought up again. If not for the Prince of Wei arranging this marriage with the Prince of Huaiyin, Li Cheng might have married Xun Rou.

However, Granny Chao and the others were different. Their livelihoods were tied to the Little Prince, so they had to be more concerned.

Princess De Yin in the Eastern Palace was also quite pleased at this moment. The Crown Prince had bestowed silks and treasures upon her, while the Crown Princess received very little. Today, the Crown Prince said he would come to see her again, making her feel that she had made the right choice.

Lianzhi and Yunzhi were also happy. Lianzhi said, "The kitchen has sent over your ginseng soup first, and Xiao Luzi said you can just tell the kitchen whatever you'd like to eat."

Yunzhi added, "Miss, once you bear the Crown Prince’s first grandson, the Eastern Palace will truly be bustling."

The first grandson—in her past life, her younger sister Huiyin became Empress Dowager by giving birth to a son. Speaking of Huiyin, she asked the servants, "By this time, the second miss should have been married off to Xuzhou, right?"

Lianzhi nodded, "Your servant estimates that she should have arrived by now."

"Miss, the Prince of Huaiyin was originally supposed to marry you, but the second miss took the chance," Yunzhi quickly added.

De Yin smiled without saying a word. She would never forget how, in her past life, after marrying, she was neglected for many days and ridiculed everywhere. To make matters worse, Li Cheng returned injured, and Granny Chao secretly advised her not to consummate the marriage, as the Empress Dowager might scold her for being like Daji or Mo Xi, which would harm the Little Prince’s recovery. De Yin had listened.

During Li Cheng's recovery, she began managing the mansion but was framed and could not defend herself. She was sent to Jianye.

That place was like a den of dragons and tigers, and Li Cheng, a man who couldn’t distinguish right from wrong, had no feelings for her, unlike Li Heng, who doted on her exclusively. She would have to endure this marriage. No, she couldn’t think like that. Although Ji had committed many evil deeds, Huiyin had done nothing wrong.

Back in the bridal chamber, Li Cheng, hearing Princess Huiyin’s words, said, "I naturally see you as my wife."

Huiyin knew they weren’t very familiar yet, so expecting vows of eternal love immediately was unrealistic, but she needed to express her stance. Seeing that Li Cheng’s response was just a formality, she didn’t press further and simply said, "Then let’s rest early."

The dragon and phoenix candles had to burn all night and couldn’t be extinguished, so Huiyin had trouble sleeping due to the light. But because she had been through so much that day, she was exhausted and, despite the light, fell asleep quickly.

When she woke up the next morning, Li Cheng was no longer beside her. She rang the bell to summon the servants to assist her with her hair and makeup.

Unexpectedly, Granny Chao also entered, her expression unpleasant. Huiyin looked at her, unsure of what was happening, but she didn’t need to ask and simply pretended not to know. If she humbly sought advice, she might be manipulated.

Granny Chao saw the several maids surrounding Princess Zheng as they styled her hair and applied her makeup. Granny Chao still maintained some respect for the Princess. Once Huiyin’s makeup was nearly complete, Granny Chao finally said, "Young Princess, I have something to discuss with you."

Huiyin pretended to understand and frowned slightly, "I noticed you seemed hesitant to speak earlier. Do you have something to say?"

"Yes, Your Highness, I have an important matter to discuss with you," Granny Chao emphasized the word “important.”

"Then please, do tell," Huiyin replied, dismissing the servants. Once they were alone, she said, "What is it that you need, Granny? Please, have a seat."

Granny Chao smiled and said, "The Young Princess has come from afar. Ideally, the wedding should have taken place in Jianye so you could meet the Grand Dowager Wu and the Prince of Wei and other relatives. However, the Little Prince is stationed in Xuzhou, so it has been quite an inconvenience for you."

"Mother, that's just a figure of speech. As the saying goes, 'a woman must follow her man, wherever he leads.' Don't worry, I don't feel wronged at all," Huiyin said with a smile, knowing that Granny Chao was being courteous before getting to the main issue.

As expected, Granny Chao praised her, "It's truly reassuring for us old servants of the Little Prince to have such an understanding princess." But then her tone shifted, "However, the Little Prince is currently injured and needs quiet rest. We can't have both of you crowded in here, can we? This way, neither of you will sleep well."

Granny Chao thought she had already spoken quite tactfully.

Huiyin frowned and said, "Indeed, I feel deeply sorry seeing the Little Prince's shoulder injury. Why don't you go and speak to the Little Prince? He can choose where he wants to stay. I have no objections. Actually, I told him yesterday that I would sleep on the pallet and let him sleep on the bed."

"How can I possibly say that to the Little Prince?" Granny Chao immediately rejected the idea.

Huiyin thought to herself, if she's so good at talking, why doesn't she talk to Li Cheng directly? It's not that Li Cheng can't move on his own; why should his wife, who has only known him for one night, refuse him entry?

Therefore, Huiyin directly threw the issue back to Granny Chao. Let her deal with the unpleasant task. Don't take me for a fool.

Granny Chao looked at Huiyin and realized this was a tricky situation. As a wet nurse, she shouldn’t meddle in the private affairs of the Little Prince and the young princess.

What if the Little Prince wants to be intimate with his wife?

Huiyin smiled and said, "Granny Chao, let’s settle it this way. You go and speak to the Little Prince. By the way, the other day, since we weren’t officially wed, it wouldn’t have been appropriate for me to give you a reward. Today, I’ve specially prepared a generous gift for you."

Granny Chao looked at Huiyin and thought, this young princess is quite shrewd.

Chapter 10

◎Excessive Execution Power◎

"Little Princess, the Prince requests your presence in the main hall to introduce you to the court officials," Yun Hui said.

Yun Hui, daughter of Granny Chao, was different from her mother. She was very formal and precise. It was said that after her fiancé died, she chose to remain unmarried and bound her hair. She served as the head housekeeper, responsible for liaising between the inner and outer courts.

Huiyin glanced at Granny Chao, "Mother, I will go then."

Granny Chao had unspeakable bitterness.

At this moment, Li Cheng had changed into a dark blue robe embroidered with golden purple flowers, looking radiant and showing no trace of his injuries. He smiled as he looked at Huiyin, "Princess, please come here, let me introduce you."

Huiyin nodded and bowed slightly before sitting down. Li Cheng introduced a man with a goatee beard, "This is my military strategist, Jian Qin."

"Good day, Advisor Jian," Huiyin stood up and returned the greeting with a smile. Though Jian Qin looked like an ordinary, thin old man, being the first to be introduced by Li Cheng indicated that he was a trusted aide.

Li Cheng then introduced Zhonglangjiang Yuwendang, General Guowei Zhao, among others. Yuwendang had a stern face and a tall figure, while Zhao was robust with a scar on his brow. There were also some civil officials, all of whom Huiyin met one by one.

Huiyin was very composed. She did not accept their courtesies with arrogance but instead only accepted half the courtesy in return. After meeting them, she did not steal the show but instead congratulated Li Cheng, "Congratulations, Prince, on having such excellent and strong generals. You will surely have divine assistance in the future."

"Thank you for the auspicious words, Princess," Li Cheng smiled.

Huiyin said, "I brought many specialties from Jizhou. Thanks to the Prince's grace, I have the opportunity to meet everyone today and have prepared some gifts for you. Please do not refuse them."

Li Cheng was unaware that Huiyin had prepared gifts. Of course, she had been preparing these gifts for several days, knowing well how her mother had managed her father's subordinates with great discretion.

The gifts were not overly extravagant or unsettling but were specialties from Jizhou, including two boxes of walnut-patterned black dates, two boxes of donkey meat jerky, two jars of Congtai wine, a bundle of golden-thread noodles, six bolts of lock-stitch embroidered silk, and a piece of Dingzhou purple silk tapestry. The most eye-catching item was the filigree-inlaid golden guardian.

Though the guardian was only palm-sized, it was crafted using welding, filigree, and coiling techniques, modeled after a tiger with mythological variations, making it a lively and playful piece.

Li Cheng nodded secretly, acknowledging that although Princess Zheng was young, she was quite knowledgeable about etiquette.

After the gifts were brought in, Huiyin took her leave, not really intending to stay and listen to their praises.

The gift list was likely written by her personally, and her handwriting was also very good.

By the time this was done, it was noon, and the food began to be served. One of Huiyin's good points was her appetite. Though she was from the north, she did not mind eating rice. Especially when the sauce of the crystal pork knuckle was poured over the rice grains, it was truly delicious.

She was not as slender and delicate as the women of the Jiangnan region and appeared more plump. She did not diet intentionally but ate heartily.

Nanny Nan smiled, "Miss has never been picky since she was young. Many of us can't get used to these southern dishes. They say the noodles have sugar, and the soy sauce is too much, but you eat them with relish."

"Nanny, we shouldn't keep saying these things about the southerners. If the Little Prince hears, what will he think? North and south, aren't we all people of the same country? As for the dishes on the table, we eat more of what we like and less of what we don't. The Little Prince invited me to meet his subordinates today, showing that he respects me. In a few days, I will talk to him about adding another stove, and you can cook your own meals." Huiyin said.

Nanny Nan nodded hurriedly, "We all have a better future following the Princess."

Huiyin lifted her chin, "Of course, since we are married into Xuzhou, we must live a fulfilling and flavorful life."

After the meal, she took a nap, and the room quieted down as the servants retreated.

Granny Chao was also somewhat troubled, "Our new Princess is cunning. The Little Prince is injured, but she doesn't care at all. She just dismissed me."

Even sitting in a chair, Yun Hui maintained a straight posture, "Mother, you should interfere less in the Little Prince's personal affairs. I understand you're concerned about his health, but if you talk too much, the Prince will become impatient."

"My child, I understand this reasoning, but our lives are tied to the Little Prince. If something happens to him, what will happen to us, a widow and an orphan?" Granny Chao was worried both for herself and for Li Cheng.

She blamed Huiyin in her heart. As a Princess, she indulged in pleasure and neglected the Little Prince. Granny Chao was determined to report this to the Dowager Princess.

Yun Hui comforted her, "Don't overthink it. The Little Prince's injuries aren't serious. Moreover, I find that the young princess acts with integrity and propriety. Even the civil and military officials praise her."

"That's just flattery. Humph, I was truly concerned for her. If she were aligned with me, I wouldn't mind telling her some things. But she views her own kin as enemies. She may face dire consequences in the future." Granny Chao snorted.

Yun Hui was puzzled, "What do you mean by that?"

Granny Chao looked at her daughter, "Don’t you understand what I’m saying, or the Empress Dowager’s temperament?"

The Empress Dowager Wu was originally a consort of the late emperor. After much hardship, she gave birth to Prince Wu, but Prince Wu was raised by the favored consort, Huang Zhaoyi, and was not close to his birth mother but to Consort Huang. Empress Dowager Wu deeply resented this situation. Later, when her daughter-in-law, Miss Cui, gave birth to a son, Li Cheng, the Empress Dowager wanted to raise him. But Miss Cui, from the prestigious Cui family of Boling and the daughter of General Cui Xun, refused to let Empress Dowager Wu take her only son.

It was only after the deaths of Prince Wu and his wife that the Prince of Huaiyin and the Empress Dowager depended on each other, gradually forming a bond. The Empress Dowager hoped her niece, Xun Rou, would marry the Little Prince. Xun Rou could almost manage the household of the mansion in Jianye and even made efforts to remove any women who were slightly more presentable around the Little Prince.

The Little Prince never rejected marrying Xun Rou, but as he was a filial son, he insisted on observing mourning before marriage, which led to his marriage with Princess Zheng.

A sure thing had flown away. Naturally, the Empress Dowager wouldn't do anything to the Little Prince, but would she treat the young princess kindly?

……

The dinner brought was stewed quail, stir-fried chicken mushrooms, and deep-fried spring goose. As the meal was being set out, Li Cheng entered, and Huiyin hurriedly went forward to welcome him.

Li Cheng was somewhat curious, "Which dish did you make?"

Huiyin was stunned for a moment. He was serious? She had only mentioned cooking casually. She said, "I heard we’re supposed to sleep in separate rooms today, so I thought you wouldn't come over, and thus I..."

"Separate rooms? Who said that?" Li Cheng had no intention of sleeping separately on his wedding night. Today, his wife had generously rewarded his subordinates, so he had to come over.

Huiyin, of course, wouldn't mention Granny Chao. One shouldn’t create distance in close relationships. So she smiled, "Then tomorrow I'll cook some soup for you. What do you like to eat?"

Li Cheng, thinking she had actually prepared something special today, joked, "Do you think you can make whatever I like?"

"I can learn if I don't know how." Huiyin sat down with him, not finding it a difficult task.

Li Cheng nodded almost imperceptibly. Huiyin thought, no matter how ruthless a man is, there's a significant difference between having intimacy and not.

Additionally, she noticed something. Most people would delay tasks, but he wasn’t like that. He did what was expected during the wedding night, even with injuries. Yesterday, she casually mentioned cooking, and he immediately came over.

Well, she was the type to be decisive in big matters but procrastinate on small ones, even lazing in bed. Her new husband seemed to be someone with excessive execution.
